utterances: On Joe's other point though, public opinion polls in the Arab world show that al-Qaeda and its ideology are increasingly less popular.
Indeed, Neal.
I mean - and that's human nature.
Because when the bombs go off in another country, you don't care about it, but when they start going off on your own doorstep - it took 9/11 for the United States to wake up for this problem.
So, when the bomb started going off in Iraq,al-Qaeda lost popularity.
When the beheadings, the suicide attacks, etcetera, the bombs starting going off in Saudi Arabia, al-Qaeda in Saudi Arabia started losing popularity.
Support for suicide bombing in Pakistan has dropped from 33 percent five years ago to eight percent now.
So, you know, that is reality and that's in the long- term, this is - that's very damaging toal-Qaeda's ability to continue to recruit.
But, you know, the caveat there is small groups of people can influence history.
Look at the Brigate Rossi or the Baader-Meinhof gangs in the 70s in Italy and Germany.
These were very small terrorist groups with zero popular support, yet they conflicted a great deal of damage on Germany and Italy.
So, even asal-Qaeda's popularity wanes, that doesn't mean they're out of business.
Joe, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
And the other thing is, what about the targets of al-Qaeda?

As we've looked at their inability to mount successful attacks in western Europe and the United States, we have seen though, continued attacks in other places, obviously, Iraq has been a - from their point of view - a disappointment but there have been others as well.
Well, I mean, you know, obviously, the Iraq playbook was imported to Afghanistan.
You go back to 2003, there are one or two suicide attacks in Afghanistan.
Last year, there were 140.
So, the tactics and ideology thatal-Qaeda was involved in in Iraq have migrated to Afghanistan.
We're also seeing in Pakistan, there were 60 suicide attacks last year, which is more suicide attacks in one year than they've had in their entire history.
So, while they may not be able to attack in Western Europe or the United States - although it's easier for them to attack in Western Europe, the United States is a harder target.
But, you know, clearly, mounting a suicide operation in Pakistan is very easy for these groups.
We've seen them happen every week.
And what about targets in the Arab world?
There was a great threat in Saudi Arabia, for example.
Well - and that has reduced a little bit in Saudi Arabia, but you may recall the attacks in Egypt on the Taba Hilton which killed a number of people.
The attacks in the Sinai and the Red Sea resorts, we've seen an attack in Jordan that killed 60 at American-owned hotels in 2005.
So, they continue to have an ability to do these kinds of attacks in the Middle East.
Peter Bergen is with us.
He's from the New America Foundation and his most recent book, ""The Osama Bin Laden I Know."" About seven years after 9/11, we are talking about whetheral-Qaeda remains our number one priority.
Is it your number one priority?
Give us a call, 800-989-8255.
Email is talk@npr.org.
We'll continue the conversation in just a moment.
I am Neal Conan.
You're listening to Talk Of The Nation, from NPR News.

This is Talk Of The Nation.
I am Neal Conan in Washington.
And Peter, when we ask people if al-Qaeda and Osama bin Laden are still their number one priority, opinion polls suggest that's no longer the case.
Yeah.
They - I mean, obviously, the economy plays much more loudly in people's fears and hopes than al-Qaeda does and, you know, I think that's just human nature.
The threat is now seven years behind us.
It seems - al-Qaeda doesn't seem to have an ability to attack us, at least for the medium and short-term.
I just, you know, that's just human nature.
That doesn't mean thatal-Qaeda suddenly has decided to go out of business just because Americans no longer consider the group a threat.
Yes.
I think that's the right thing to do.
I mean, what looked like a model victory may become a model defeat if we don't get our act together in Afghanistan.
And we know from Iraq that if the right group of people start rethinking the policies, you can have a favorable impact now.
Of course,Petraeus is going from Iraq to (unintelligible), which includes Afghanistan and Pakistan as part of his area of responsibility.
We've got a new Pakistani government, you're going to have a new American government.
I think the time has come right to really look at a strategic reset in Afghanistan and of course in Pakistan.
They're one - it's all part of the same problem in a sense.
Peter Bergen as always.
Thanks very much for being with us today.

Peter Bergen of the New America Foundation joined us here in Studio A.
In just a moment, This American Moment.
The latest unemployment report shows the jobless rate is basically stuck where it has been, and that's not good news.
The private sector added fewer jobs than economists expected and government jobs disappeared.
The jobs report released yesterday is the last one before November's midterm elections.
NPR's White House correspondent Ari Shapiro reports on how elected officials are dealing with it.
The unemployment report prompted dueling speeches at small businesses 500 miles apart from each other.
In Maryland, President Obama visited a concrete products company.
Now, these are the guys that build serious stuff: concrete blocks, bricks - for walls that are thick, difficult to move and can stop anything in their path.
Sort of like the way I feel about Congress sometimes.
Congressman John Boehner is proud to have obstructed the president's agenda.
He hopes to be speaker if Republicans take back the House in three weeks.
Yesterday, Boehner gave a speech of his own at a small business in his home district.
The pink slips shouldn't be going to workers here in Ohio, they should be going to the members of President Obama's economic team.
Both men talked a lot about how small businesses are struggling in this economy, but they gave utterly different views.
First, President Obama argued that Republicans stood in the way of government programs that would give small businesses easier access to cash.
Thousands of small business owners across America had been waiting for months for this bill to pass, for the loans and tax cuts they've badly needed to grow their businesses and hire new employees.
Unfortunately, it was held up all summer by a partisan minority until a few courageous Republican senators put politics aside.
But back in Ohio, Congressman Boehner said the answer is for government to get out of the way and stop spending taxpayer money on ineffective programs.
Unidentified People: No.
Unidentified People: No.
Hell no, you don't.
(SOUNDBITE OF APPLAUSE)
Yesterday's numbers showed that unemployment has now been above nine- and-a-half percent for 14 months - that's longer since any time since the 1930s.
Everybody knows this hole is the deepest since 1929, and I think that just confirms what people knew.
This is Austan Goolsbee, the new chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
While Mr. Obama was speaking in Maryland, Goolsbee was at the White House trying to put the unemployment numbers in context.
All you can do is start at the bottom and work your way out.
And he clearly came in at the bottom, and we're just trying to slowly work our way out of this.
It will succeed.

Businesses are coming back - slowly.
In September, the private sector added 64,000 jobs, which is about average for the last nine months.

Well, we'd like to see, you know, consistent monthly gains of 150 to 200 thousand per month.
Really bring the unemployment rate down in a meaningful way.
That means job growth needs to more than double, and until it does, Dye says, people in office will be voted out.
A bad economy - and I think a 9.6 percent unemployment rate qualifies as a bad economy - going into an election is bad news for incumbents.
It doesn't matter what party you're in.
If you're an incumbent in this election, watch out.
Ari Shapiro, NPR News, the White House.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Back in December, the United States Sentencing Commission changed the federal sentencing guidelines and will now retroactively reduce sentences for crack cocaine offenders.
They we're typically sentenced to 50 percent more jail time than powder cocaine offenders.
The new guidelines take effect this coming Monday.
Just over 1,500 convicts can apply for immediate release, and an additional 19,000 could be eligible for shorter sentences over the next 30 years.
But all of them will have served lengthy terms in prison.
After many years inside, ex-prisoners face challenges as they try to figure out a world that's changed a great deal over the past 10 or 20 or 30 years.
There are big issues like employment and housing discrimination, and lots of smaller ones, like feeling overwhelmed by technology and culture.
If you'd like to talk with former prisoners about dealing with those changes, give us a call.
Or, if you've been through this experience yourself, what surprised you?
Give us your story.

E-mail: talk@npr.org.
And you can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
